case_name: L. S. Lalvani v. Custodian of Evacuee Properties

facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 414-416 of 1963 appealed to Supreme Court from Kerala High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 414- 416 of 1963. Appeals from the judgment and order dated December 6, 1960 of the Kerala High Court in A.S. Nos. 445 and 484 of 1960.

facts.text: Kerala High Court judgment and order dated December 6, 1960 in A.S. Nos. 445 and 484 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 416 of 1963. Appeals from the judgment and order dated December 6, 1960 of the Kerala High Court in A.S. Nos. 445 and 484 of 1960. Mahalingier and K. N. Keswai, for the appellant  In both the appeals

facts.text: Proprietors of firms Adam Haji Peer Mohd. Essack and Haji Ebrahim Kasim Cochinwala migrated to Pakistan in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The proprietors of two firms styled Adam Haji Peer Mohd. Essack and Haji Ebrahim Kasim Cochinwala had, in the year 1947, migrated to Pakistan and both these firms became vested in the Custodian of Evacuee Properties for the State of Madras under s. 8 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950,

facts.text: Firms became vested in the Custodian of Evacuee Properties for the State of Madras under s. 8 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: migrated to Pakistan and both these firms became vested in the Custodian of Evacuee Properties for the State of Madras under s. 8 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950, hereinafter referred to as the 1950 Act.

facts.text: Appellant appointed as Manager of the two firms on March 6, 1952 under s. 10(2)(b) of the 1950 Act.

anchor.surface_text: On March 6, 1952 the appellant was appointed as Manager of the two firms under S. 10 2   b  of the 1950 Act. The appellant also furnished security of Rs. 20,000/- before taking possession of the business of the firms as Manager.

facts.text: Appellant furnished security of Rs. 20,000 before taking possession as Manager.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant was appointed as Manager of the two firms under S. 10 2   b  of the 1950 Act. The appellant also furnished security of Rs. 20,000/- before taking possession of the business of the firms as Manager.

facts.text: Order of appointment Ex. P-1 dated March 6, 1952 issued by Custodian.

anchor.surface_text: The order of appointment-Ex. P-1 dated March 6, 1952 states The Custodian approves the proposal of the Deputy Custodian, Malabar that the Management of both the firms of Adam Hajee Peer Muhammad Issack and Hajee Ibrahim Kassam Cochinwala at Kozhikode may be allotted to Sri L. S. Lalvani for the present on the same system as exists number between the Government and the present two managers and on his furnishing a security of Rs. 20,000 to the satisfaction of the Deputy Custodian.

facts.text: Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954 passed on October 9, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On October 9, 1954 the Displaced Persons  Compensation and Rehabilitation  Act, 1954 was passed which will hereafter be referred to as the 1954 Act.

facts.text: Advertisement published in the Press for sale of evacuee properties on April 11, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On April 11, 1956 there was an advertisement published in the Press for the sale of the aforesaid evacuee properties.

facts.text: Appellant applied to the Chief Settlement Commissioner to stop the sale.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied to the Chief Settlement Commissioner for stopping the sale of the two companycerns.

facts.text: Central Government order Ex. P-5 dated April 25, 1956 decided in principle to allot evacuee concerns to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On April 25, 1956 the Central Government made an order-Ex. P-5 -which states I am directed to state that it has been decided in principle that the aforesaid evacuee companycerns will be allotted to you. The terms of allotment will be companymunicated to you separately.

facts.text: Letter P-8 dated June 21, 1956 stated firms to be allotted and ultimately sold to appellant L. S. Lalvani.

anchor.surface_text: On June 21, 1956 another letter-P-8-was written to the appellant by the Custodian of Evacuee Properties which states The Deputy Custodian is informed that the Government of India have decided that the two evacuee companycerns viz., firms of Adam Hajee Peer Mohammed Essack and Hajee Ebrahim Kassam Cochinwala of Kozhikode are to be allotted to the present Manager Shri L. S. Lalvani and ultimately sold to him.

facts.text: Advertisement in Press about public auction of business of firms on March 25, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The bargain was number companycluded and on March 25, 1958 there was an advertisement in the Press about the public auction of the business of the firms.

facts.text: Appellant moved Kerala High Court for writ restraining District Collector from selling by public auction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved the High Court of Kerala for grant of a writ restraining the District Collector from selling the business of the firms by a public auction.

facts.text: Kerala High Court on June 25, 1959 directed District Collector not to sell without order of Chief Settlement Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The application was allowed and on June 25, J959 the Kerala High Court directed the District Collector number to sell the properties of the business of the two firms without an appropriate order of the Chief Settlement Commissioner.

facts.text: Chief Settlement Commissioner order for sale made on September 15, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the order of the Chief Settlement Commissioner was subsequently made on September 15, 1959.

facts.text: Management of appellant terminated and possession taken by Deputy Custodian Respondent 1.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of that order the management of the appellant was terminated and the possession of the business was taken over by the Deputy Custodian--Respondent number 1.

facts.text: Order Ex. P-13 dated December 18, 1959 terminated services of L. S. Lalvani as Manager.

anchor.surface_text: The order-Ex. P-13 dated December 18, 1959 states Shri L. S. Lalvani is informed that his services as Manager of the business companycerns of Adam Haji Peer Mohd. Essack and Haji Ibrahim Kassam, Cochinwala, at Kozhikode are hereby terminated with immediate effect.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition O.P. 1438 of 1959 in Kerala High Court for certiorari and mandamus.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court of Kerala being O.P. number 1438 of 1959 for grant of  1  a writ of certiorari for quashing the order dated December 15, 1959--Ex. P-13 -and the proceedings dated December 18, 1959-Ex. P-16,

facts.text: Single Judge S. Velu Pillai by order dated June 8, 1960 granted writ restraining sale by public auction.

anchor.surface_text: S. Velu Pillai, J. by his order dated June 8, 1960, granted writ to the appellant as prayed for restraining the respondents from selling the business by public auction.

facts.text: Respondents filed appeal A.S. 484 of 1960, appellant filed A.S. 445 of 1960 in Kerala High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of the Single Judge the respondents filed an appeal being S. number 484 of 1960 before the Division Bench of the High Court. The appellant also preferred an appeal A.S. number 445 of 1960

facts.text: Division Bench of Kerala High Court by judgment dated December 6, 1960 dismissed A.S. 445 of 1960 and allowed A.S. 484 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: By judgment dated December 6, 1960 the Division Bench of the High Cl/65-9 Court dismissed Appeal A.S. number 445 of 1960 filed by the appellant but allowed the appeal A.S. number 484 of 1960 filed by the respondents.

facts.text: Present appeals brought by certificate of Kerala High Court under Art. 133(1)(a) of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeals are brought on behalf of the appellant by certificate of the Kerala High Court granted under Art. 1 3 3   1    a  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant claimed indefeasible right of management under order Ex. P-1 dated March 6, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued by the Counsel on behalf of the appellant that an indefeasible right of management was companyferred upon the appellant because of the, order of the Custodian-Ex. P-1 dated March 6, 1952.

facts.text: Court held appellant lawfully removed from management by order dated December 18, 1959 under s.10(2)(b) read with s.16 General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the management of the appellant with regard to the business companycerns can lawfully be terminated by the Deputy Custodian by virtue of s. 10 2   b  of the 1950 Act read with s. 16 of the General Clauses Act.
under s. 8 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950, hereinafter referred to as the 1950 Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 of the General Clauses Act states Where, by any Central Act or Regulation, a power to make any appointment is conferred, then, unless a different intention appears, the authority having for the time being power to make the appointment shall also have power to suspend or dismiss any person appointed whether by itself or any other authority in exercise of that power.

concepts.interpretation: Power to appoint includes power to suspend or dismiss unless different intention

issues.text: whether the appellant was lawfully removed from the management of the business by the order of the respondent number 1 dated December 18, 1959Ex. P-13 and P-16

anchor.surface_text: The first question arising in this case is whether the appellant was lawfully removed from the management of the business by the order of the respondent number 1 dated December 18, 1959Ex. P-13 and P-16. It was submitted on behalf of the appellant that under s. 10 2   b

issues.text: whether under s. 10 2   b  of the 1950 Act the Custodian had the power to appoint a Manager for the Evacuee Property for carrying on any business of the evacuee and there was numberpower conferred by the Act upon the Custodian to remove the Manager so appointed

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted on behalf of the appellant that under s. 10 2   b  of the 1950 Act the Custodian had the power to appoint a Manager for the Evacuee Property for carrying on any business of the evacuee and there was numberpower conferred by the Act upon the Custodian to remove the Manager so appointed.

issues.text: whether the order of removal-Ex. P-13 and P-16-was made by the Managing Officer-cum-Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property of Southern States under the 1954 Act which conferred numberpower on such an officer to cancel the appointment of a Manager

anchor.surface_text: It was then companytended on behalf of the appellant that the order of removal-Ex. P-13 and P-16-was made by the Managing Officer-cum-Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property of Southern States under the 1954 Act which conferred numberpower on such an officer to cancel the appointment of a Manager.

issues.text: whether the order of removal of the appellant from the management is valid because Mr. Mathur had the legal competence to make the order under the 1950 Act, though he has also described himself in that order as Managing Officer

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the order Ex. P- 13 and P-16 is signed by Mr. Mathur as the Managing Officer-cum-Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property but the order of removal of the appellant from the management is valid because Mr. Mathur had the legal competence to make the order under the 1950 Act,

issues.text: whether the appellant is entitled to move the High Court for grant of a writ in the nature of mandamus under Art. 226 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: But even on the assumption that the order of the Deputy Custodian terminating the management of the appellant is illegal, the appellant is number entitled to move the High Court for grant of a writ in the nature of mandamus under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended for the appellant that in view of Ex. P-5 dated April 25, 1956 there was final allotment of the business, though the terms of allotment had to be subsequently determined.

arguments.claim: under s. 10(2)(b) of the 1950 Act the Custodian had the power to appoint a Manager for the Evacuee Property for carrying on any business of the evacuee and there was no power conferred by the Act upon the Custodian to remove the Manager so appointed

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted on behalf of the appellant that under s. 10 2   b  of the 1950 Act the Custodian had the power to appoint a Manager for the Evacuee Property for carrying on any business of the evacuee and there was numberpower conferred by the Act upon the Custodian to remove the Manager so appointed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Power of appointment under s.10(2)(b) implies power to terminate via s.16 General Clauses Act

arguments.claim: in view of Ex. P-5 dated April 25, 1956 there was final allotment of the business, though the terms of allotment had to be subsequently determined

anchor.surface_text: It was contended for the appellant that in view of Ex. P-5 dated April 25, 1956 there was final allotment of the business, though the terms of allotment had to be subsequently determined.

arguments.court_reasoning: No final terms settled, no concluded contract of sale; letters indicate 'in principle' only

arguments.claim: the management of the appellant with regard to the business concerns can lawfully be terminated by the Deputy Custodian by virtue of s. 10(2)(b) of the 1950 Act read with s. 16 of the General Clauses Act

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the management of the appellant with regard to the business companycerns can lawfully be terminated by the Deputy Custodian by virtue of s. 10 2   b  of the 1950 Act read with s. 16 of the General Clauses Act.

arguments.claim: when an authority passes an order which is within its competence, it cannot fail merely because it purports to be made under a wrong provision if it can be shown to be within its power under any other rule

anchor.surface_text: It is well- established that when an authority passes an order which is within its competence, it cannot fail merely because it purports to be made under a wrong provision if it can be shown to be within its power under any other rule, and the validity of the impugned order should be judged on a consideration of its substance and number of its form.

arguments.claim: a writ of mandamus may be granted only in a case where there is a statutory duty imposed upon the officer concerned and there is a failure on the part of that officer to discharge that statutory obligation

anchor.surface_text: The reason is that a writ of mandamus may be granted only in a case where there is a statutory duty imposed upon the officer companycerned and there is a failure on the part of that officer to discharge that statutory obli- gation.

arguments.claim: the terms and conditions of allotment were not finally settled between the parties and there was no concluded contract of sale and, therefore, the appellant had no legal right to the business

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the terms and companyditions of allotment were number finally settled between the parties and there was numberconcluded companytact of sale and, therefore, the appellant had numberlegal right to the business of the two companycerns

holdings.text: It is manifest that the management of the appellant with regard to the business concerns can lawfully be terminated by the Deputy Custodian by virtue of s. 10(2)(b) of the 1950 Act read with s. 16 of the General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the management of the appellant with regard to the business concerns can lawfully be terminated by the Deputy Custodian by virtue of s. 10 2   b  of the 1950 Act read with s. 16 of the General Clauses Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power of appointment under s.10(2)(b) implies power to terminate as per s.16 General Clauses Act unless contrary intention

holdings.text: The power of appointment conferred upon the Custodian under s. 10(2)(b) of the 1950 Act confers, by implication, upon the Custodian the power to suspend or dismiss any person appointed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no warrant for this argument. The power of appointment conferred upon the Custodian under s. 10  2   b  of the 1950 Act confers, by implication, upon the Custodian the power to suspend or dismiss any person appointed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory power to appoint includes power to remove via implication and s.16 General Clauses Act

holdings.text: Under s. 10(2)(b) of the 1950 Act the Deputy Custodian is the proper authority to cancel the appointment of a Manager and the order-Ex. P-13 and P-16 dated December 18, 1959 is, therefore, legally valid.

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 10 2   b  of the 1950 Act the Deputy Custodian is the proper authority to cancel the appointment of a Manager and the order-Ex. P-13 and P-16 dated December 18, 1959 is, therefore, legally valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1950 Act provisions continue in force; Deputy Custodian competent despite 1954 Act mention

holdings.text: It is well-established that when an authority passes an order which is within its competence, it cannot fail merely because it purports to be made under a wrong provision if it can be shown to be within its power under any other rule, and the validity of the impugned order should be judged on a consideration of its substance and not of its form.

anchor.surface_text: It is well- established that when an authority passes an order which is within its competence, it cannot fail merely because it purports to be made under a wrong provision if it can be shown to be within its power under any other rule, and the validity of the impugned order should be judged on a consideration of its substance and not of its form.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine of substance over form; order valid under correct provision (1950 Act) despite wrong label

holdings.text: The appellant is not entitled to move the High Court for grant of a writ in the nature of mandamus under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: But even on the assumption that the order of the Deputy Custodian terminating the management of the appellant is illegal, the appellant is not entitled to move the High Court for grant of a writ in the nature of mandamus under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandamus only for statutory public duties, not contractual obligations from managerial appointment

holdings.text: There was no final allotment of the business in favour of the appellant by the Chief Settlement Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: We pass on to consider the next question presented on behalf of the appellant viz., whether there was a final allotment of the business in favour of the appellant by the Chief Settlement Commissioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No final terms settled; no concluded contract despite 'in principle' decisions in letters

holdings.text: It is manifest that the terms and conditions of allotment were not finally settled between the parties and there was no concluded contract of sale and, therefore, the appellant had no legal right to the business of the two concerns.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Letters indicate provisional 'in principle' allotment pending terms; no binding sale contract formed

precedents.citation: Balakotaiah v. The Union of India 1958 S.C.R. 1052 at p. 1059

anchor.surface_text: Balakotaiah v. The Union of India.   1

precedents.cited_proposition: when an authority passes an order which is within its competence, it cannot fail merely because it purports to be made under a wrong provision if it can be shown to be within its power under any other rule, and the validity of the impugned order should be judged on a consideration of its substance and not of its form; we must ascribe the Act of a public servant to an actual existing authority under which it would have validity rather than to one under which it would be void

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay Presidency and Aden v. Bombay Trust Corporation Ltd. 63 I.A. 408

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay Presidency and Aden v. Bombay Trust Corporation Ltd.  1

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay Presidency and Aden v Bombay Trust Corporation Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: mandamus can issue to a public servant only if a duty towards the applicant has been imposed upon the public servant by statute independently of any duty he may owe to the Crown
precedents.cited_holding: Before mandamus can issue to a public servant it must therefore be shown that a duty towards the applicant has been imposed upon the public servant by statute so that he can be charged thereon, and independently of any duty which as servant he may owe to the Crown, his principal

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the management of the appellant with regard to the business concerns can lawfully be terminated by the Deputy Custodian by virtue of s. 10 2   b  of the 1950 Act read with s. 16 of the General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is well- established that when an authority passes an order which is within its competence, it cannot fail merely because it purports to be made under a wrong provision if it can be shown to be within its power under any other rule, and the validity of the impugned order should be judged on a consideration of its substance and not of its form.
